College of Chemistry Fuzhou University Fuzhou Fujian 350108 China Designing high-performance catalyst is vital in the field of CO2 methanolization. In this study, two In3Ru surfaces (In3Ru_i and In3Ru_r) were employed as computational models and the density functional theory was applied to study the influence of surface In/Ru ratio on their surface morphologies, reaction mechanisms and catalysis performance for methanol synthesis. Surface characterization reveals that In3Ru_i is higher in surface In/Ru ratio than In3Ru_r, and such difference facilitates CO2 adsorption on In3Ru_r. Being different in surface In/Ru ratio, two surfaces exhibit distinct variations in the reaction mechanism of methanol formation. For In3Ru_i, the “Formate” pathway dominates the first CO2 activation step which leads to methanol production. On the other hand, In3Ru_r prefers the “reverse water-gas shift” pathway (RWGS) in the initial step of CO2 activation, but this mechanism is unable to generate CH3OH due to the kinetic limitation of CO* hydrogenation. Based on the microkinetic modeling, In3Ru_i is superior in both CO2 production rate and CH3OH selectivity than the other one, suggesting higher surface In/Ru ratio benefits methanol formation, which complies well with the experiment. Overall, our study offers a new perspective with respect to how surface morphology of the bimetallic catalyst influences the reaction mechanisms of CO2 hydrogenation. How to deal with the excess CO2 waste and alleviate its harmful resultant such as global warming and the increase of sea levels have become a global issue [1–4]. Among various approaches been put forward to deal with this issue, Carbon dioxide Capture and Utilization (CCU) is a very efficient and economic one due to several advantages: (1) directly reducing the CO2 emission; (2) using the renewable energy in water electrolysis to produce the hydrogen gas; (3) taking advantage of CO2 as a carbon feedstocks to manufacture the high-valued C1 product industrially (e.g., methane, methanol and CO) [5–10]. In particular, CO2 hydrogenation to methanol (CO2 + 3H2 = CH3OH + H2O) has attracted extensive attention because methanol is a vital industrial material and could be treated as the alternative of fossile fuel [11–15]. Similar as the nitrogen gas, CO2 is very stable in the atmosphere and thereby requires both the catalysts and relatively higher temperature to activate the molecule. To date, the industrial realization of this reaction is available by pumping into the feed gas (mainly CO2, H2 and CO) over a trinary catalyst Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 under the environment of 5–10 MPa and 493–573 K [16,17]. Compared with the high conversion rate of CO2, this strategy remains very low in methanol selectivity (< 32 %) due to the fact that high temperature boosts the CO formation from the reverse water-gas shift reaction (CO2 + H2 = CO + H2O) which is an endothermic process [18,19]. Hence, a suitable catalyst should be well designed to satisfy both the need for higher selectivity of methanol and conversion rate of CO2 at low temperature. Being encouraged by the first example, many researches in this area focus on taking advantage of the reducible metal-oxides (e.g. CeO2, ZrO2, ZnO and In2O3) and their derivatives as the catalyst because of their high activity towards the methanol formation [20–24]. Besides, bimetallic catalysts which comprises of different metal components have gradually received more attention and become another important class of catalyst in CO2 methonalization [25,26]. In comparison with both of its monometal counterparts, different components inside alloys could interact with each other and impose a synergy effect on catalysts. When this occurs, the structural and electronic configuration of the catalyst would be greatly altered, which in turns enhances the overall performance of the catalyst. In parallel with the Cu-Pd alloy which has been extensively researched experimentally and theoretically by Song et al. and other groups, [27–32] we have seen various good examples of In-based catalyst. For example, Snider et al., found that In2O3 could be partially reduced when it is alloyed with Pd and the synergy effect between In2O3 and PdIn significantly improve the selectivity of CH3OH relative to the mono-Pd catalysts [33] SiO2 supported In-Pd designed by Ye et al., was also found to reduce the activity towards H2 dissociative adsorption when compared with the Pd monometallic particles [34]. More recently, Li et al., designed a In-Rh catalyst which exhibits high selectivity and activity towards CO2 methanolization under the H2-difficient environment [35]. As can be seen from these examples that In addition significantly improves the catalytic performance of the alloys towards methanol formation. Apart from Pd and Rh, In addition could enhance the catalysis behavior of Ru nanoparticles as well. Experiment results suggest that incorporation of In into Ru nanoparticles generates the In-Ru bimetallic catalyst which exhibit high activity and selectivity towards methanol formation [36]. Furthermore, this catalyst displays little inclination towards methane formation which is generally reported to be the dominant product on the metallic or supported Ru surface [37–40]. The promotion effect of the catalyst has been attributed primarily to the formation of tetragonal-In3Ru (space group: P42/mnm) which displays different crystalline planes under different reducing temperature. Accordingly, surface characterization shows that In3Ru is dominated by the (212) facet when it is reduced under 450 K and such temperature leads to the optimal performance of the catalyst (both CO2 conversion rate and CH3OH selectivity). The same facet has been observed in tegragonal-In3Rh as well which turns out to exhibit high reactivity towards CO2 methanation [35]. Quite contrary to the (110) and (001) planes, the exposed-In and Ru atoms are more randomly distributed along the (212) facet and therefore makes it more difficult to study the synergy effect between In and Ru. By increasing or decreasing the number of the top-layered In atoms, the numbers of undercoordinated Ru atoms will change and this could cause the variations in electronic and structural properties of the In3Ru surface and ultimately lead to difference in reaction mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation. All of these issues have not been taken seriously in the experiment and should therefore be further discussed. On account of this, we employed density functional theory (DFT) to systematically study the surface of In3Ru(212) and analyze the impact with respect to the degree of Pd exposure on their surface morphology and catalytic performance towards methanol formation. 2 Computational methods 2.1 DFT calculation methods In this study, all the spin-polarized DFT calculations with periodic boundary was performed on Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP)[41] which uses the projector augmented wave (PAW) to solve Kohn-Sham equations and describe the valence electrons and core interaction [42,43]. The exchange and correlation energies were described by the spin-polarized generalized gradient approximation (GGA) functional in conjunction with the Perdew−Burke−Ernzerhof functional (PBE) format [44]. Before structural optimization, we employed the convergence tests on both k-point and the energy cutoff. Based on the results, the Kohn-Sham orbital is expanded using plane waves with 400 eV energy cutoff and a (2 × 2 × 1) k-point grid using Monkhorst−Pack scheme were applied in this study [45]. Dispersion corrected vdW-D3 functional proposed by Grimme was used to describe the van der Waals effect [46]. All structures including the surface models and intermediates (INT) were optimized using the conjugated-gradient (CG) method and the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method was employed to locate the transition states (TS) [47]. The vibrational frequencies of the structure found by CI-NEB method were further evaluated to see if it has only one imaginary vibrational frequency along the reaction coordinate and whether the predicted TS connects the initial state (IS) and final state (FS). For all structures considered in this study, the local relaxation was allowed to stop before the forces on all atoms were less than 0.03 eV/Å. The Bader charge analysis was employed to analyze the electronic properties of the key intermediate and transition state in our study [48,49] 2.2 Surface models According to the experiment results, In3Ru is the major component of the In-Ru bimetallic catalyst under 450 K and 800 K, which remains over 86 % in CH3OH selectivity. In comparison with the one of 800 K, In3Ru being reduced under 450 K is approximately 2 times in CO2 conversion rate and the HR-TEM images reveal that it is dominated by (212) facet. As displayed in Fig. S1, the optimized lattice parameters of the tetragonal-In3Ru unit cell is a = 7.02 Å, b = 7.02 Å and c = 7.24 Å, which agrees well with the experiment and calculation results reported by Takagiwa et al. and PÖttgen et al. [50,51]. As displayed in Fig. 1 a, b, two different types of In3Ru (212) (denoted as In3Ru_i and In3Ru_r) were modeled from the bulk t-In3Ru using a 1 × 2 supercell with three atomic layers (96 atoms in total), and each layer contains 32 atoms including 8 Ru and 24 In. Moreover, In3Ru_i could transform into In3Ru_r through removing two uppermost In atoms (In4 and In9) from its surface while keeping the total number of atoms unchanged. The active Ru atoms (act_Ru) is defined as the top-layered Ru whose coordination number to the top-layered In is lower than 5 and such threshold was set to select the more undercoordinated Ru atoms from all exposed-Ru atoms. For geometry optimization of both surface models, the bottom layer of In3Ru slab was fixed at their original positions while the rest were allowed to fully relax and a 15 Å vacuum slab was applied to avoid the interaction between each adjacent slab. To evaluate the kinetic stability of both surface models, AIMD simulation was used in our calculations. In specific, NVT ensemble is employed where the temperature is set as 500 K. EDIFF is set as 1E-4, the simulation period and each time step are set as 5 ps and 1 fs, respectively. As displayed in Fig. 1c, d, both surface models remain constant without obvious distortion in configuration after a period of 5 ps. All structures were built and visualized from Materials Studio [52]. In addition, the free energies of the gaseous species were calculated as: G g ( T ) = E elec + E ZPE + ∫ C p d T − T S Where C p represents the heat capacity of gaseous species as a function of T , which is obtained from the NIST Website[53]. 2.3 Microkinetic modeling To evaluate the overall turnover frequencies (TOF) of CH3OH formation on both surfaces, the catalysis microkinetic analysis package CatMAP developed by Nørskov's group is employed to simulate its reaction kinetics underthe pressure and temperature of 1–10 MPa and 400–1000 K, respectively [54]. For both In3Ru_i and In3Ru_r, two different adsorption sites were considered for hydrogen, including t_site for the ones binding to the exposed-Ru atom and v_site for the others binding to the exposed-In atoms. Otherwise, the adsorption sites which are occupied by the remaining adsorbates are all assigned to s_site. In this manner, hydrogen could be treated as an independent species adsorbing at a special “hydrogen reservoir” site which prevents it from competing for the free site with the other species. The maximum surface coverage for each site is summed to 1 ML to ignore multilayer adsorption and the initial concentration ratio of CO2, H2, CH3OH, H2O and CO in the gas-phase was set as 0.249: 0.749: 0.001: 0.001: 0.0001. Furthermore, the degree of rate control (DRC) method popularized by Campbell's group was performed to determine the rate-limiting step during CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [55]. The sum of all X R C , i coefficients have to obey the following rule: ∑ i X R C , i = 1 DRC value being positive corresponds to the rate-controlling transition state, being negative corresponds to the rate-controlling intermediate and represents neither of both if its value is close to zero. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphological and electronic properties of both surfaces As displayed in Fig. 1a, b, there are four different types of exposed-Ru atoms observed on the top layer of both In3Ru_i and In3Ru_r, wherein Ru1 and Ru3 are solely coordinated to In atoms. The coordination behaviors of Ru2 and Ru4 are quite different from the other two types because these two atoms could not only establish the linkage to each other but also maintain the rest connections to In atoms. For In3Ru_i, the coordination numbers of both Ru1 and Ru3 to top-layered In are 4 and 3, respectively, which are lower than the other two exposed-Ru atoms from the top layer (5 for both Ru2 and Ru4). Hence, both Ru1 and Ru3 are the ones that fit our criteria for act_Ru. For In3Ru_r surface, Ru1 and Ru4 exhibit the same binding behavior as the ones observed in In3Ru_i, so their coordination number to In atoms remains unchanged. However, when In3Ru_r is generated by removing In4 from In3Ru_i, the respective coordination number of Ru2 reduces to 4 and thereby turning itself into the act_Ru. Even though Ru3 loses Ru3-In9 bonding after In9 removal, this drives it to get closer to In11 and establish the Ru3-In11 linkage. Hence, the coordination of Ru3 remains almost unchanged. In comparison with In3Ru_i, one more act_Ru (Ru2) is found on the top layer of In3Ru_r, which therefore becomes lower in surface In/Ru ratio. In addition to structural variation, we also comparatively studied the electronic differences between two surfaces by investigating the Bader charge on four top-layered Ru atoms. As displayed in Fig. 1, the charge of Ru1 and Ru4 remains constant for both surfaces, which is consistent with their identical coordination number to top-layered In. On the contrary, the charge of Ru2 and Ru3 decreases by 0.13 and 0.12, respectively, as a result of In4 and In9 removal. We speculated that such change will cause a dramatic difference on the adsorption behavior of the reactants and reaction mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation, both of which will be discussed in detail in the following section. 3.2 Adsorption and dissociation behavior of H2 on both surfaces Before delving into the reaction mechanisms of methanol formation on both surfaces, we should initiate by studying the way how both reactants interact with the surface. Having this idea in mind, the adsorption and dissociation behavior of H2 was examined firstly since the process of CO2 hydrogenation will be heavily influenced by surface coverage of the atomic hydrogen. As mentioned above, the atomic arrangement from the top layers of both In3Ru_i and In3Ru_r is very disordered and this increases the difficulties of finding the best activation sites for H2. Hence, we began by manually placing the atomic hydrogen on all possible positions including the top, bridged and hollow sites, and these configurations of the initial guess were allowed to locally relax before the force criterion was met. Fig. 2 a, b displays the relative positions of all individually adsorbed H* along with the number of their corresponding configurations on both surfaces after structural optimization. It is noticed that a total number of 8 and 7 configurations were located on In3Ru_i and In3Ru_r, respectively. In3Ru_r has one fewer structure due to the fact that H* could hardly be stabilized between In1 and In2, which causes the configuration No. 1 to be very unstable and quickly transforms into configuration No.2. For In3Ru_i surface, the adsorption sites for atomic hydrogen could generally fall into two categories: either the one bridging between two In atoms (No. of configurations: 1, 2, 7, 8) or the other one on the top of Ru atoms (No. of configurations: 3, 4, 5, 6). When H* is stabilized by two In atoms, the adsorption energy is between 0.36–0.47 eV, which is much higher than binding H* in the other manners whose adsorption energies vary from −0.57 to −0.46 eV. For most adsorption configurations of H*, the difference of binding strength between two surfaces are quite small, so a similar trend is observed for In3Ru_r surface which is found to be much more inclined to accommodate the hydrogen atom on the exposed-Ru atoms (including act_Ru). However, it is noticed that H* adsorbed on In3Ru_r is much stronger in binding strength for configuration No. 2 and 7, both of which are lower in adsorption energy by 0.52 and 0.24 eV, respectively. For these two configurations, the adsorbed H* binds to In1 and In12, and surface characterization of In3Ru_i suggests that both sites are neighboring to In4 and In9, respectively. As a result, In1 and In12 become more undercoordinated and active towards H*-adsorption when both In4 and In9 are removed from the surface transformation. In addition to In1, the absence of In4 also enhances the adsorption ability of Ru2 towards H* whose adsorption energy is lower by 0.17 eV relative to its counterpart on In3Ru_i. All the above discussions reveal that Ru atoms are very active towards interacting with H*, which is consistent with the previous theoretical results [56,57]. By comparison with the other two Ru atoms, Ru1 and Ru3 are determined to be the active sites for hydrogen gas on both surfaces since they are close to each and slightly more favorable in binding to H*. To continue, we kept on studying the way with respect to how H2 interacts with the active site on both surfaces. As displayed in Fig. 3 , the physisorbed structure i_H2_IS is the only stable adsorption configuration of H2 we found on In3Ru_i surface, and it could readily undergo bond cleavage with the assistance of the active site and generates two hydrogen atoms binding to both Ru1 and Ru3, respectively. The CI-NEB result shown in Fig. S4 suggest that the bond dissociation of the physisorbed H2 is a barrierless process since we observed a continuous decrease in energetics for all climbing images along the reaction coordinates. The facile H2 activation is also evidenced by the formation of a very stable i_H2_FS which lowers the reaction energy by 1.03 eV relative to its initial state. On the other hand, H2 could be stabilized by Ru1 without breaking apart on In3Ru_r surface and this configuration is exothermic by 0.97 eV in adsorption energy. Similar as the one we found on In3Ru_i, H2 is also very active towards further bond dissociation at the active site with the energetics of the TS nearly the same as that of IS. This process ends with a coadsorption configuration of two atomic hydrogen binding to both Ru1 and Ru3, respectively, with the reaction energy being as low as −0.04 eV. On the basis of these findings, it is found that the process of H2 activation is rather facile on both surfaces suggesting they could provide enough atomic H for CO2 hydrogenation. 3.3 Adsorption behavior of CO2 on both surfaces Subsequently, the adsorption behavior of various CO2 modes as well as their energetics were examined on both surfaces. Fig. 4 a, b displays the adsorbed CO2 configurations of the most stable ones and the ones which initiates the first elementary step of CO2 hydrogenation (including both “Formate” and “RWGS” pathways), and their corresponding structural parameters (related to CO1, CO2 and angles of O1-C-O2) are summarized in Table S1. For In3Ru_i surface, the most energetically favorable CO2 structure is i_CO2_1 which is a chemisorbed mode and has an adsorption energy of −0.30 eV. It exhibits a tridentated configuration with the calculated O1-C-O2 angle of 122.2° by coordinating O1, C and O2 to Ru1, Ru3 and In10, respectively. By comparing the bond distance, we found that CO1 is more elongated than CO2 by 0.04 Å, whereas O1-Ru1 is shorter than O2-In by 0.40 Å. It is therefore evidenced that the oxygen atom from CO2 prefers to bind to Ru atom and O-Ru interaction promotes the activation of CO bond. Quite contrary to that of the most stable one, physisorbed CO2 exhibits linear structure and both of its CO bonds experience little fluctuation relative to its gaseous phase. Even though being slightly lower binding strength, it is later found that this mode could serve as the starting configuration of the “Formate” pathway. To continue, we further examined the structural properties of i_CO2_3 that triggers the “RWGS” pathway during CO2 hydrogenation. Upon its adsorption, both of the oxygen atoms are coordinated to two exposed-In atoms (In4 and In8) while the remaining carbon atom are bonded by Ru2, and the distance of both CO1 and CO2 linkages are 1.30 and 1.28 Å, respectively. The calculated adsorption energy of this CO2 mode is −0.20 eV, which is slightly higher than that of i_CO2_1 even though they are similar in configuration. The inferior in binding strength for i_CO2_3 could be attributed to O2-In interaction being weaker than O2-Ru interaction in i_CO2_1. As for i_CO2_4 shown in Fig. S5, its adsorption process is endothermic in nature by requesting for an extra energy of 0.28 eV, so it is a very unstable configuration and could hardly be found at low temperature. Unlike two aforementioned chemisorbed configurations being tridentate, i_CO2_4 exhibits a bidentate structure and both of its O1 and C are coordinated to two exposed-In atoms which further hinders its stabilization. Next, we paid our attention to In3Ru_r surface which also has five different CO2 adsorption modes. First of all, we found that r_CO2_1 is both the most favorable structure and the starting CO2 configuration for the “RWGS” mechanism on In3Ru_r surface. Despite of sharing the similar structure as i_CO2_3, it is much more stable with an adsorption energy of −0.64 eV. As shown in Fig. S6, r_CO2_2 and r_CO2_3 are the second and third most stable CO2 configuration on In3Ru_r and their adsorption energies are −0.45 and −0.36 eV, respectively. For the former one, r_CO2_2 differs from the most stabilized CO2 in that In6 rather than In8 is the adsorption site for O2. In comparison with In6 which is involved in direct binding to In4, In8 is little affected by In4 removal and thereby shows lower reactivity towards O2 coordination. As for the other one, we found that both r_CO2_3 and i_CO2_1 are the corresponding CO2 configuration on both surfaces. When In3Ru_r is employed as our surface model, O2-coordinated In10 becomes more unsaturated in coordination number owing to the In9 removal, so we observed a more stable CO2 configuration in comparison with its counterpart on In3Ru_i. Unlike other CO2 modes we found, physisorbed CO2 mode is the starting configuration of the “Formate” pathway and its adsorption energy is lower than the ones have already been discussed. However, it is still stronger in binding strength than r_CO2_4 which is the most unfavorable CO2 configuration on In3Ru_r surface. 3.4 First elementary step of CO2 hydrogenation on both surfaces It is widely accepted that the first elementary step of CO2 hydrogenation plays a significant role in determination of the overall reaction route for CH3OH formation. Since the adsorption behavior of CO2 as well as the activation manner of H2 has been examined individually, in this part, we will further our research by investigating how both reactants interact with each other in the first step. Generally, two mechanisms are taken into account for the bimetallic catalyst system: (1) the “Formate” pathway wherein the formate species (HCOO*) is generated from CO2 hydrogenation and (2) the "RWGS" pathway in which CO2 is protonated to the carboxyl species (COOH*) [24,27–29]. Throughout our studies, the adsorbed H* is treated as the hydrogen source for hydrogenation or protonation related elementary steps since the bond dissociation of H2 is a facile process on both surfaces. As a start, we examined both mechanisms for In3Ru_i surface, the potential energy diagram of which are displayed in Fig. 5 . The “Formate” pathway initiates with the coexistent configuration of i_CO2_4 and H* on the top of Ru2. In the TS configuration, bending of the linear-shaped CO2 and elongation of the Ru2-H distance occur at the same time for CH interaction and this requires a kinetic energy of 0.55 eV. When CH distance is further shrunk to 1.11 Å, HCOO* is produced which bridges between In6 and In8 using both of its oxygen atoms and this process is almost thermoneutral energetically. On the other hand, the “RWGS” pathway initiates with configuration of both i_CO2_3 and H* at the bridge site between In2 and In4. To meet with the protonation process, a high kinetic barrier of 1.48 eV is needed which makes O2 of CO2 lose connection to In4 and reduces O2-H distance to 1.60 Å in the transition state. This pathway ends with the formation of trans-COOH* which stabilize the system by 0.67 eV relative to its initial state. In addition to i_CO2_3, it is also found that i_CO2_1 could be further protonated to COOH*. However, this pathway is very unlikely to happen under low temperature since the calculated kinetic barrier is as high as 1.81 eV (refer to Fig. S7 for more information). By comparison, the “Formate” pathway is more competitive than the “RWGS” pathway from the kinetic aspect, suggesting CH bond formation should precede OH bond formation at low temperature. Moreover, adsorption analysis of the individual species reveals that i_CO2_1 from IS of the “RWGS” pathway is higher in adsorption energy than H* from IS of the “Formate” pathway. Being lower in binding strength makes CO2 become less competitive thermodynamically in coordination to Ru3 in comparison with H*, and such situation could get worse when it comes to a H2-rich environment. Based on these findings, the “Formate pathway” is the dominant reaction mechanism on In3Ru_i surface. Next, both mechanisms are examined individually on the In3Ru_r surface with their potential energy diagram displayed in Fig. 6 . Similar as that of In3Ru_i, the “Formate” pathway also begins with the structure of physisorbed CO2 (r_CO2_4) which coadsorbs with H at Ru3. In the TS configuration, a 0.61 eV kinetic barrier should be overcome and the CH distance is reduced to 1.46 Å. This process generates a bi-HCOO as its resultant which is nearly thermoneutral as its initial state. In both cases, HCOO is produced from the interaction between a physisorbed CO2 and surface hydrogen atom, and this is so called the Eley-Rideal mechanism [58,59]. As a matter of fact, such mechanism has been already reported in the process of methanol formation via CO2 hydrogenation catalyzed by the bimetallic alloys or transition-metal oxide [28,60]. On the other hand, CO2 could also undergo the “RWGS” pathway which starts with the coadsorption configuration of r_CO2_1 and H* bridging between In1 and In5. In the TS configuration, O2-In5 linkage is broken so that O2 of CO2 could approach H* and reduces their distance to 1.48 Å. After overcoming a 0.47 eV kinetic barrier, the trans-COOH* is produced and this process is exothermic by 0.66 eV. As the activation energy of OH bond formation is lower than CH bond formation, it is found that In3Ru_i exhibits a reverse trend with respect to the kinetics of two mechanisms by comparison with In3Ru_r. In addition to this, the “RWGS” pathway is thermodynamically preferable by forming a more stable intermediate, and both of these factors reveal that it is the dominant reaction pathway on In3Ru_r surface. 3.5 The integrated reaction route towards methanol and CO formation through CO2 hydrogenation on both surfaces The previous section reveals that both surface models choose different reaction mechanisms as their preferred ones in the first elementary step (the “Formate pathway” for In3Ru_i and the “RWGS” pathway for In3Ru_r). However, determination of the most favorable reaction route towards methanol formation lies on every other elementary steps beside this one. Hence, we further examined the integrated reaction routes towards methanol formation through CO2 hydrogenation on both In3Ru_i and In3Ru_r. 3.5.1 The integrated reaction route towards methanol formation (through “Formate” pathway) on In3Ru_i surface We began by examining the reaction route controlled by the “Formate” pathway in the first step. As displayed in Fig. 7 , after HCOO* is produced through facile interaction between a physisorbed CO2 and H* (I1), it could be further hydrogenated by getting access to H* bridged between In9 and In10 (I2). The kinetic energy for this step is 0.98 eV and H2COO* formation comes along with elevation of energetics by 0.37 eV. Structural examination of the final state reveals that the H2COO* uses O1 to bind to both In8 and In10 while its O2 is solely coordinated to In6, displaying a structure different from the traditional bi-H2COO. For the next step, H2COO* could be further protonated and renders H2COOH* as its product by acceptance of the H* bridging between In2 and In4 (I3). The corresponding kinetic barrier and reaction energy are 0.62 and −0.40 eV, respectively, suggesting this step is feasible from both kinetic and thermodynamic aspect. The generated H2COOH* could experience a CO bond cleavage process and generates the [CH2O + OH]* as its FS configuration (I4), which raises energetics of the system by 0.41 eV. However, increasing in reaction energy does not influence the rate of this step as it is kinetically favorable with the required activation energy being only 0.60 eV. We then individually examined the reaction potential for both OH* (I5–1) and CH2O* (I5–2), and the hydrogenation product of which are H2O* and CH3O*, respectively. For the former one, the activation energy of H2O formation (OH* + H* =H2O*, I5–1) is 0.72 eV and this step is found to be endothermic by 0.26 eV. As for the other one, CH3O* formation encounters subtle difficulties in kinetics owing to the low activation energy of its TS configuration. This step is followed by methanol production (I6) with a 0.80 eV kinetic barrier and gasification of the product is endothermic by 0.58 eV. 3.5.2 The integrated reaction route towards CO formation (through “RWGS” pathway) on In3Ru_i surface The carboxyl species is also the potential product for the initial step of CO2 activation which could subsequently transform into both CO and methanol, and this mechanism is so called the “RWGS” mechanism. As displayed in Fig. 7, after COOH* is produced (I7), a CO bond dissociation occurs very fast by producing [CO + OH]* as its FS configuration (I8), and the reaction barrier and energy for this elementary step are 0.22 and −1.40 eV, respectively. The thermodynamic advantage of this step could be attributed to the fact that OH* displays direct linkage to In4, In5 as well as In9 and this tridentate configuration significantly increases its binding strength. For the next two elementary steps, OH* and CO* could be further hydrogenated and generate H2O* and CHO* (I9) as their respective resultant. Owing to its stability, OH* is unable to be directly hydrogenated but needs to migrate to the bridge site between In4 and In6 and then undergoes the process exactly the same as that of step I5–1 within the “Formate” pathway. On the other hand, the process of CO* hydrogenation is examined as well, but it is found that methanol formation is unavailable through this mechanism because both the reaction barrier and energy for this step are very high. As a result, the “RWGS” pathway only leads to formation of CO* which could desorb from the catalyst surface by additional 2.08 eV in energetics. 3.5.3 The integrated reaction route towards methanol formation (through “Formate” pathway) on In3Ru_r surface As displayed in Fig. 8 , the “Formate” pathway on In3Ru_r leads to facile formation of HCOO* which could be further hydrogenated to H2COO*(R2). With the distance between HCOO* and H* on the top of In10 become shorter in the TS configuration, this elementary step has to overcome a 0.65 eV activation energy before the formation of H2COO*. In the final state, both O1 and O2 from H2COO* exhibit bridging configuration between two surface atoms and such multiple-bonding structure significantly enhances the adsorption capacity of H2COO*. Hence, we noticed that step R2 is exothermic by 0.57 eV in energetics and this characteristic in reaction energy is very different from step I2 on In3Ru_i surface which is found to be intrinsically endothermic. However, intermediate being too strong in binding strength also limits the reaction rate of next elementary step (protonation of H2COO*, R3) which has a much higher kinetic barrier than its counterpart on In3Ru_i (I3). Subsequently, H2COOH could undergoes the process of CO bond dissociation and this could be achieved in two manners depending on whether the assistance of H* is needed. Energetically, cleavage of the CO bond directly without H* involvement is unlikely to proceed as it is featured by a very high activation energy and unstable [CH2O + OH]* coadsorbed species in the final state. By comparison, H-participation largely reduces the reaction energy by affording H2O* as the coexisting species beside CH2O*, so it is determined to be the more favorable mechanism (R4). When H is involved in step R4, CO bond cleavage and OH formation happens simultaneously in the TS configuration and elevates its activation energy to 1.23 eV. For the last two elementary steps before methanol formation, the kinetic energy required from CH2O* hydrogenation (R5) and CH3O* protonation (R6) are 0.81 and 0.93 eV, respectively. 3.5.4 The integrated reaction route towards CO formation (through “RWGS” pathway) on In3Ru_i surface As displayed in Fig. 8, being promoted by both the low activation barrier and reaction energy, COOH* could undergoes CO bond dissociation (R8) after CO2 protonation (R7). This elementary step generates the stable coexisting species OH* and CO*, both of which will be examined with respect to their activation potential. In terms of the former one, OH* hydrogenation is a retarded process as evidenced by the activation energy being as high as 1.44 eV. As for the other one, CO* is generally regarded as the key intermediate during the process of methanol formation when CO2 activation is dominated by the “RWGS” pathway and the process with respect to CO* hydrogenation could help us evaluate the feasibility of this mechanism. Similar as that of step I9, CO* is very stable and its hydrogenation on In3Ru_r is kinetically hindered as well owing to the high activation energy needed for the interaction between CO* and H* in the TS configuration. Due to the stability of CO*, formation of carbon monoxide is also difficult and both findings suggest that methanol formation is not viable via the “RWGS” mechanism. 3.5.5 Microkinetic modeling Based on our DFT calculations, it is found that methanol formation on both surfaces is lead by the “Formate” rather than the “RWGS” pathway, which generates only CO as its product. For both In3Ru_i and In3Ru_r, the effective barriers of the whole reaction route during CH3OH synthesis are 1.47 and 1.67 eV, respectively, so it appears that In3Ru_i is better in catalyzing the methanol formation than In3Ru_r on the basis of the potential energy diagram. To further support this point of view, microkinetic modeling analysis was employed to calculate the logarithm values of turnover frequency (log(TOF)) for both methanol and CO, and their corresponding elementary steps on both surfaces are summarized in Tables S2 and S3, respectively. As displayed in Fig. 9 a-b, on In3Ru_i surface, the log(TOF) value of both CH3OH and CO increases with the temperature indicating that temperature increment promotes the production for both products. In specific, we noticed that CH3OH is more advantageous in product selectivity than CO on In3Ru_i since its log(TOF) values remains higher than that of the other within our investigated temperature range. Owing to the endothermic nature of the “RWGS” reaction, the product preference for CH3OH reaches its maximum at temperature as low as 400 K and gradually becomes weaker when temperature rises. This finding suggests that methanol and carbon monoxide are the major products on In3Ru_i at lower and higher temperature range, respectively. As displayed in Fig. 9c-d, In3Ru_r generally follows a similar trend as that of In3Ru_i when it comes to log(TOF) change of the two product with the temperature. However, CH3OH is not the preferable product for In3Ru_r because its log(TOF) value remains lower than that of CO even at low temperature. Hence, CO is determined to be the dominant product on In3Ru_r, which thereby reduces its selectivity towards methanol. Moreover, both surface models were compared with each in terms of their catalysis performance towards methanol production rate at lower temperature. When T < 600 K, the log(TOF) value of CH3OH remains higher for In3Ru_i over In3Ru_r, suggesting higher methanol production rate could be guaranteed by taking In3Ru_i as the catalyst. Furthermore, the degree of rate control analysis (DRC) suggested by Campell group was employed to evaluate the step that limits the reaction rate for both products which are displayed in Fig. S10. On In3Ru_i surface, HCOO* hydrogenation (I2) and the CO2* protonation (I7) are the corresponding rate-determining step for producing both CH3OH and CO. On the other hand, as displayed in Fig. S11, the reaction rate of methanol production on In3Ru_r is limited by HCOO* hydrogenation (R2) at low temperature, which is gradually replaced by the H-assisted bond dissociation of H2COOH* (R4) when the temperature begins to increase. Likewise, OH hydrogenation (R9–1) limits the reaction rate for CO production on In3Ru_r surface at low temperature, but it becomes replaced by CO2 protonation as the temperature rises. 4 Discussions 4.1 The influence of water on the catalyst performance of In3Ru_i for methanol formation Our results in Section 3 suggest that In3Ru_i is better in performing the catalysis of methanol formation from CO2 hydrogenation owing to relatively higher production rate and selectivity of the target product than In3Ru_r. However, it should be noted that the calculated log(TOF) value of CH3OH is still not high enough at low temperature (−17.7 at 533 K), which seems to contradict with the high CH3OH production rate of In-Ru alloys observed in the experiment [26]. Therefore, we speculated that other factors should be taken into account to further examine the whole reaction route during the methanol formation. For all types of reaction involved with CO2 hydrogenation, it is generally accepted that water is the major side product and its presence in the system could affect the adsorption behavior of key intermediates and activation energy of transition state, both of which could further influence the rate and even catalysis mechanism of the reaction. For example, the presence of water on the defective In2O3 could coexist with the carboxyl species and thereby hinders the hydrogenation of CO* generated from the “RWGS”mechanism [61]. Likewise, Song et al., discovered that water could not only alter rate-determining step of the reaction, but also increase reaction rate of CH3OH production [27,28]. Besides, in his study, a water molecule is explicitly introduced in the reaction system for each elementary step and water could interact with other intermediates in two ways: (1) the “H-shuttled” mechanism in which H2O serves as a “shuttle” and transfer the H* to the adsorbate, This mechanism generally applies to the process of both CO bond cleavage and OH bond formation during methanol formation; (2) the “H2O-solvated” mechanism wherein H2O does not directly participate in the reaction the intermediate and only serves as a “spectator”. This mechanism works well with the elementary steps involving CH bond formation. Inspired by Song's study, we also evaluated the extent of “hydration effect” on each elementary step in the process of CO2 hydrogenation. To be more specific, the activation energy difference ( Δ E a ) of the corresponding elementary steps with and without water are expressed as follow: Δ E a = E a ′ − E a wherein E a ′ and E a denote the activation of the step without and with H2O, respectively. As displayed in Fig. 10 , except for W4 and W8, the Δ E a values for most elementary steps of CO2 hydrogenation are positive suggesting both methanol and CO production are benefited from H2O inclusion. In addition, the “hydration effect” experiences large fluctuation in dimension among different elementary steps and it is noticed that such variation depends strongly on the reaction mechanism of the steps. For elementary steps involved with OH formation, H2O inclusion in the system reduces the kinetic barrier by more than 0.23 eV and these steps include W3, W5–1, W6, and W7. On the other hand, elementary steps except for the aforementioned ones are classified as either CH formation or CO bond cleavage. We noticed that these steps are less affected by introducing H2O in the system because their corresponding activation energy decreases by less than 0.15 eV or even increases for W4 and W8. These findings comply well with Song's research showing that steps associated with OH interaction are kinetically beneficial from the “hydration effect” in comparison with that of CH and CO interaction. To unveil the reason behind the promotion effect of H2O on OH bond formation, we further examined the electronic properties of both TS configurations for CH3O* protonation with and without H2O. In order to elucidate the direction of charge transfer within both structures, the adsorbed species were further divided into two moieties in which H3Oδ or Hδ is the first part (denoted as part I) while the remaining fragments (CH3Oδ) are all included in the second part (denoted as part II). As displayed in Fig. 11 , for both TS configurations, charge is observed to transfer from part I to part II, so they become either more electron deficient or more electron rich, respectively. For the H2O-absent system, the charges for both Hδ and CH3Oδ are +0.05 and −0.54, respectively, suggesting that H* is ineffective in donating the electron to part II. By comparison, H3Oδ is more positively charged (+0.22) while CH3Oδ is more negatively charged (−0.64) in the H2O-included system and this contributes to the electronic interaction between two parts which could stabilize the transition state. The enhanced electronic interaction inside TS configuration is further revealed by the charge difference analysis revealing that two areas are mainly accumulated with excess of charge when H3Oδ loses electron: (1) between H2O and adsorbed H* in the H3Oδ moiety; (2) between H3Oδ and CH3Oδ. To evaluate the “hydration effect” on the catalyst performance, we further calculated the production rate and selectivity of target product on In3Ru_i with H2O inclusion and compared them to the one without H2O. As displayed in Fig. S12, the TOF value of CH3OH in the presence of water is 1.01 × 10 − 17 at 533 K, which is 4.76 times higher than the one without H2O. Moreover, at the same temperature, the TOF value of CO quickly decreases to 1.81 × 10 − 24 and become much lower than that of CH3OH when H2O is not included in the system. On the basis of this finding, it is concluded that the catalyst performance of In3Ru_i could be greatly enhanced by introducing water in the reaction system. 4.2 The influence with respect to the ratio of surface In/Ru on catalyst performance of In3Ru_i for methanol formation According to the experiment results, the reduction temperature has a huge effect on the performance of In3Ru catalyst. It is observed that In3Ru being reduced under 450 K has a much higher CH3OH production rate than the one being reduced under 300 K. When the reduction temperature rises from 300 to 450 K, more In atoms become incorporated into the In-Ru alloys and this morphological change gradually increases surface In/Ru ratio of In3Ru catalyst. For both surface models employed in our study, removing both top-layered In atoms from In3Ru_i generates In3Ru_r which therefore has a lower ratio of surface In/Ru than In3Ru_i and this could bring about several changes in its catalyst performance towards methanol formation. As mentioned earlier, active Ru atom binds strongly to the oxygen atom and thereby increases the binding strength of chemisorbed CO2, which is the starting configuration of the “RWGS” mechanism. Hence, protonation becomes more favorable on In3Ru_r and precedes an hydrogenation in the first activation step of CO2, which leads to the facile formation of CO*. Compared with that of In3Ru_i, CO* on In3Ru_r is calculated to be more stabilized by 0.47 eV in energetics (see Table S4 for more information) and it is observed to be linear-shaped by adsorbing firmly at the active Ru atom which coincide with the DRIFTS study for In3Ru catalyst reduced under 300 K. However, the “RWGS” pathway could hardly lead to formation of the final product since CO* is too stable to undergo further activation, so it is concluded that methanol formation on In3Ru_r is dominated by the “Formate” pathway as well. Our findings comply well with the experiment results suggesting that HCOO* is the key intermediate during the process of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Moreover, lower surface In/Ru ratio of In3Ru_r also causes the over-stability of H2COOH*, H2COO* and CH2O* resulting from the “Formate” pathway, and these three species are found to be more retarded in further activation in comparison with their counterparts on In3Ru_i. In terms of the first one, stronger interaction between O and active Ru atom stabilizes H2COOH whose CO bond could only be broken by the assistance of H*. As for the other two, the adsorption energy of H2COO* and CH2O* are further lower by 0.54 and 1.09 eV when employing In3Ru_r rather In3Ru_i as the catalyst, whereas this also increases the kinetic barrier of their protonation by 0.35 and 0.60 eV, respectively. All of these factors significantly lower the production rate and selectivity of CH3OH on In3Ru_r surface. 5 Conclusions In this study, we employed density functional theory (DFT) calculation, along with microkinetic modeling (MKM) to investigate the reaction mechanism and catalyst performance associated with methanol formation from CO2 hydrogenation on In3Ru(212) surface. Both In3Ru_i and In3Ru_r being different in the surface ratio of In/Ru were used as our surface models. Based on our calculations, the activation behavior of H2 is subtly influenced by surface morphology differences since it readily undergoes bond dissociation and guarantees high coverage of atomic hydrogen on both surfaces. On the contrary, adsorption modes of CO2 experience large variation in binding strength when different surface model is applied. In comparison with In3Ru_i, In3Ru_r is more favorable in binding to CO2 owing to the more abundant active Ru atoms on the surface that strengthen the Ru-O interaction. In addition, difference in the numbers of active Ru atom also influences the reaction mechanism of methanol formation on both surfaces. For In3Ru_i surface, CO2* is weaker in binding strength than H*, so the “Formate” pathway is the mechanism that dominates the initial step of CO2 hydrogenation as well as the overall reaction route towards CH3OH production. As for In3Ru_r surface, the reversed trend of binding strength is observed between two reactants, which thereby promotes the “RWGS” pathway in the first elementary step. However, this pathway could hardly lead to methanol formation because CO* is too retarded to be further hydrogenated. On the basis of MKM results, it is found that In3Ru_i is better than the other one in both production rate and selectivity of the target product, suggesting methanol formation is more favorable on In3Ru surface with higher In/Ru raio from the top layer, which is consistent with the experiment. Further analysis reveals that inferior catalyst performance of In3Ru_r towards methanol synthesis could be attributed to over-stability of some key intermediates adsorbed at the active Ru atom during the process of CO2 hydrogenation. Our calculation results offer a new perspective with respect to the influence of surface atom upon the reaction mechanism and catalyst performance of a catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Designing high-performance catalyst is vital in the field of CO2 methanolization. In this study, two In3Ru surfaces (In3Ru_i and In3Ru_r) were employed as computational models and the density functional theory was applied to study the influence of surface In/Ru ratio on their surface morphologies, reaction mechanisms and catalysis performance for methanol synthesis. Surface characterization reveals that In3Ru_i is higher in surface In/Ru ratio than In3Ru_r, and such difference facilitates CO2 adsorption on In3Ru_r. Being different in surface In/Ru ratio, two surfaces exhibit distinct variations in the reaction mechanism of methanol formation. For In3Ru_i, the “Formate” pathway dominates the first CO2 activation step which leads to methanol production. On the other hand, In3Ru_r prefers the “reverse water-gas shift” pathway (RWGS) in the initial step of CO2 activation, but this mechanism is unable to generate CH3OH due to the kinetic limitation of CO* hydrogenation. Based on the microkinetic modeling, In3Ru_i is superior in both CO2 production rate and CH3OH selectivity than the other one, suggesting higher surface In/Ru ratio benefits methanol formation, which complies well with the experiment. Overall, our study offers a new perspective with respect to how surface morphology of the bimetallic catalyst influences the reaction mechanisms of CO2 hydrogenation.
